subject: Re: Help plz...
msgSnippet: ... benchmark.  Oddly ... effect ... several ... one ... conditions. ... outperformed ... as I am a newbie to a lot of this discussion group.. but isn t it
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Jim Dixon <jdd@d...> wrote:
> On Sun, 28 Sep 2003, trz wrote:
>
> > > FWIW I translated the Java into C++ and ran the same
benchmark. Oddly
> > > enough, the variable name length definitely has a pronounced
effect
> > > in C++. On a slow PC used as a test box, results looked like
this:
> > >
> > > Java C++ -O1 C++ -O2
> > > short 13.4s 3.2s 4.1s
> > > long 12.0s 8.4s 7.2s
> > >
> > > memory use 12.4 MB 0.8 MB 0.8 MB
>
> > with java you have to let the hotspot warm up, running the code
several
> > times to let the jvm analyze code.
>
> > Run the benchmark for some seconds, than start to measure.
>
> Like hell you do.
>
> When you are benchmarking one thing against another, you don't give
one
> preferential treatment. You run them under exactly the same
conditions.
>
> Now in this case, I was actually being kind to Java. I ignored the
> startup time. Had I done "fairer" tests, C++ would have
outperformed
> Java by a much wider margin.
>
> But the tests were absurdly biased to begin with. They were about
as

I am a 'newbie' to a lot of this discussion group.. but isn't it
slightly absurd to benchmark Java against C or C++ anyways? It
sounds like you guys are trying to compare apples to oranges. The
point of Java isn't that it is fast. I realize that some people want
to see how MUCH slower than C++ it is. That makes sense but then you
have to set some parameters for your test. Some people would want to
know the 'warmed up numbers' for real world capabilities. Others
would want to know the cold start numbers for 'benchmarking'
numbers. Depending on what information you need for your decision
making process... either of the methods could make sense.

> biased as possible towards removing all of the effects being
discussed.
>
> > To have a smaller footprint try -Xms1m.
>
> In the context of the discussion you are replying to, to have a
smaller
> footprint, run the Java through JAX. This will reduce the code
size by
> 60-70%. That will reduce your load time and memory footprint by a
similar
> amount and have, I believe, a similar effect on execution time.
>
> --
> Jim Dixon jdd@d... tel +44 117 982 0786 mobile +44 797 373 7881
